title: 108_hr1617
content: The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" establishes a program to provide grants for projects addressing railroad infrastructure deficiencies to benefit public transportation and reduce energy consumption. Eligible projects aim to improve railroad operations and reduce highway traffic congestion. The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" establishes a grant program for projects improving railroad infrastructure, including track and intermodal yard capacity, rail-road crossings, and system integration. Funding excludes operating expenses, rolling stock acquisition, and debt payment. Projects must be included in state transportation plans to be eligible for funding. The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" requires that at least 20 percent of project costs funded under the act must come from non-Federal public sources. Additionally, the act outlines the allocation of funds for eligible projects. SEC. 105 of the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" allocates 80% of grant funds to States based on a formula considering rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and grade crossings. The Secretary of Transportation has discretion over the remaining 20% for grants emphasizing projects with significant public benefit. SEC. 106 mandates that laborers and mechanics on projects funded under this title must be paid prevailing wages. SEC. 107 requires at least 10% of funds to be spent on small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. SEC. 108 provides definitions for terms used in the Act. SEC. 108 defines "rail miles" and "railroad" for this title. SEC. 201 imposes an excise tax on certain train equipment sales. A 5 percent tax is imposed on the sale of specified railroad equipment, including locomotives and rolling stock. Additionally, a 5 percent tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on such equipment within 6 months of it being placed in service, unless the part or accessory is a replacement. A 5 percent tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on specified railroad equipment, unless the part or accessory is a replacement. Installers are secondarily liable for the tax imposed. The amendments made by this section regarding railroad locomotives and rolling stock will take effect on October 1, 2003. A new subchapter on transportation by rail is added to the Internal Revenue Code, imposing a 5% tax on commuter rail transportation and a 10% tax on other rail transportation of persons. The tax is to be paid by the person making the payment. "SEC. 4242. TRANSPORTATION OF PROPERTY." A 1 percent tax is imposed on amounts paid for taxable rail transportation of property within or outside the United States. The tax applies to payments made to a person engaged in the business of transporting property by rail for hire. The tax is to be paid by the person making the payment subject to tax, except in cases where payments are made outside the United States, in which the tax is to be paid by the person to whom the property is delivered in the United States by the entity providing the last segment of the transportation. "SEC. 4243. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES." For tax purposes, "taxable rail transportation" refers to rail travel within the U.S. excluding mass transit. The term "transportation" includes layover time and deadhead service movement. Special rules apply to payments made outside the U.S. for prepaid orders and tax deductions on refunds for tickets purchased without tax payment. For tax purposes, "taxable rail transportation" in the U.S. excludes mass transit. Special rules apply to payments made outside the U.S. for prepaid orders and tax deductions on refunds for tickets purchased without tax payment. Carriers must deduct any tax due under section 4241 from refundable amounts and report uncollected taxes to the Secretary. If the tax is not paid at the time of transportation payment, the carrier providing the initial segment in the U.S. must pay the tax. The amendments made by this section regarding the National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund will take effect on October 1, 2003. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, customs duties, fuel taxes, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. The Trust Fund is available for expenditures to carry out title I. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, customs duties, fuel taxes, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. Amounts in the fund are available for expenditures to carry out title I of the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund, funded by various sources, is available for expenditures to carry out the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act.
